chapter.title: Configure and start Hibernate OGM
chapter.para: Hibernate OGM favors ease of use and convention over configuration. This makes its configuration quite minimalist by default.

section.title: Bootstrapping Hibernate OGM
section.para: Hibernate OGM can be used via the Hibernate native APIs (Session) or via the JPA APIs (EntityManager). Depending of your choice, the bootstrapping strategy is slightly different.

section.title: Using JPA
section.para: The good news is that if you use JPA as your primary API, the configuration is extremely simple. Hibernate OGM is seen as a persistence provider which you need to configure in your persistence.xml. That's it! The provider name is org.hibernate.ogm.jpa.HibernateOgmPersistence.

example.title: persistence.xml file
example.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <persistence xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/persistence" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/persistence http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/persistence/persistence_2_0.xsd" version="2.0">
<persistence-unit name="org.hibernate.ogm.tutorial.jpa" transaction-type="JTA"> <!-- Use Hibernate OGM provider: configuration will be transparent --> <provider>org.hibernate.ogm.jpa.HibernateOgmPersistence</provider> <properties> <property name="hibernate.transaction.manager_lookup_class" value="org.infinispan.transaction.lookup.JBossStandaloneJTAManagerLookup" /> </properties> </persistence-unit> </persistence>

section.para: There are a couple of things to notice:

listitem.para: there is no JDBC dialect setting
there is no JDBC setting except sometimes a jta-data-source (check for more info)
there is no DDL scheme generation options (hbm2ddl) as Infinispan does not require schemas
if you use JTA, you will need to set the transaction manager lookup strategy

section.para: It is possible to configure how to connect to Infinispan, see .
From there, simply bootstrap JPA the way you are used to with Hibernate Core:

listitem.para: via Persistence.createEntityManagerFactory
by injecting the EntityManager / EntityManagerFactory in a Java EE container
by using your favorite injection framework (CDI - Weld, Spring, Guice)

section.title: Using Hibernate Core native APIs
section.para: If you want to bootstrap Hibernate OGM using the native Hibernate APIs, you will have some more work to do.

warning.para: This process is subject to change in the near future. Prefer JPA's approach.

section.para: You need to configure a few of the internals of Hibernate OGM namely:

listitem.para: the SessionFactoryObserver: GridMetadataManager
the ConnectionProvider: NoopConnectionProvider
the NamingStrategy: OgmNamingStrategy
the PersistenceClassProvider: OgmPersisterClassProvider
the Dialect: NoopDialect

example.title: Bootstrap Hibernate OGM with Hibernate Core native APIs

section.para: There are a couple of things to notice:

listitem.para: there is no DDL scheme generation options (hbm2ddl) as Infinispan does not require schemas
you need to set the right transaction strategy and the right transaction manager lookup strategy if you use a JTA based transaction strategy (see )

section.para: It is possible to configure how to connect to Infinispan, see .

section.title: Environments
section.para: Hibernate OGM runs in various environments, pretty much what you are used to with Hibernate Core. There are however environments where it works better and has been more thoroughly tested.

section.title: In a Java EE container
section.para: You don't have to do much in this case. You need three specific settings:

listitem.para: the transaction factory
the transaction manager lookup strategy
a JTA datasource

section.para: If you use JPA, simply set the transaction-type to JTA and the transaction factory will be set for you.
If you use Hibernate Core native APIs only, then set hibernate.transaction.factory_class to either:

listitem.para: org.hibernate.transaction.CMTTransactionFactory if you use declarative transaction demarcation.
or org.hibernate.transaction.JTATransactionFactory if you manually demarcate transaction boundaries

section.para: Set the transaction manager lookup strategy to the right Java EE container. The property is hibernate.transaction.manager_lookup_class and must contain the fully qualified class name of the lookup implementation. The list of available values are listed in Hibernate Core's configuration section. For example, in JBoss AS, use org.hibernate.transaction.JBossTransactionManagerLookup.
In your persistence.xml, you also need to define an existing datasource. It is not needed by Hibernate OGM and won't be used but the JPA specification mandates this setting.

example.title: persistence.xml file
example.programlisting:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <persistence xmlns="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/persistence" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xsi:schemaLocation="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/persistence http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/persistence/persistence_2_0.xsd" version="2.0">
<persistence-unit name="org.hibernate.ogm.tutorial.jpa" transaction-type="JTA"> <!-- Use Hibernate OGM provider: configuration will be transparent --> <provider>org.hibernate.ogm.jpa.HibernateOgmPersistence</provider> <jta-data-source>java:/DefaultDS</jta-data-source> <properties> <property name="hibernate.transaction.manager_lookup_class" value="org.infinispan.transaction.lookup.JBossStandaloneJTAManagerLookup" /> </properties> </persistence-unit> </persistence>

section.para: java:DefaultDS will work for out of the box JBoss AS deployments.

section.title: In a standalone JTA environment
section.para: There is a set of common misconceptions in the Java community about JTA

listitem.para: JTA is hard to use
JTA is needed when you need transactions spanning several databases
JTA works in Java EE only
JTA is slower than "simple" transactions

section.para: None of that is true of course, let me show you how to use JBoss Transaction in a standalone environment with Hibernate OGM.
In Hibernate OGM, make sure to set the following properties:

listitem.para: transaction-type to JTA in your persistence.xml if you use JPA
or hibernate.transaction.factory_class to org.hibernate.transaction.JTATransactionFactory if you only use Hibernate Core native APIs
hibernate.transaction.factory_class to org.hibernate.transaction.JBossTSStandaloneTransactionManagerLookup in both cases.

section.title: Without JTA
section.para: While this approach works today, it does not ensure that works are done transitionally and hence won't be able to rollback your work. This will change in the future but in the mean time, such an environment is not recommended.

section.title: Configuration options
section.para: Most options from Hibernate Core and Hibernate Search are applicable to Hibernate OGM. You can pass them as you are used to do either in your persistence.xml file, your hibernate.cfg.xml file or programmatically.
There are however a couple of Hibernate OGM specific configurations:

listitem.para: hibernate.ogm.infinispan.configuration_resourcename: the resource path to the Infinispan XMl configuration file (eg com/acme/app/config/infinispan-config.xml). By default, the configuration used is Hibernate OGM's default configuration (TODO describe its behavior)
hibernate.ogm.infinispan.cachemanager_jndiname: the JNDI name containing the Infinispan CacheManager. This option is rarely used.
